word: When by the jealousy of Saul driven a fugitive into the wilderness, David, cut off from human support, leaned more heavily upon God. The uncertainty and unrest of the wilderness life, its unceasing peril, its necessity for frequent flight, the character of the men who gathered to him there--"every one that was in distress, and every one that was in debt, and everyone that was discontented" (1 Samuel 22:2)--all rendered the more essential a stern self-discipline.
